Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Hollowman9000> Zec doesn‚Äôt even have electrum support for z-transactions yet, do they?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Maybe I should clarify the announcement. Our Electrum now supports Sapling, and even transparent transactions are different in a number of ways. It doesn't have the full support for z-transactions that I believe is necessary for a good experience. Theoretically, you could send z-transactions through it, but there's more support needed to find them in your wallet, which will extend the API in a non-trivial way. We just didn't find ANY support for Sapling, even transparent txes, in any of the Electrum forks.
BTW, your issue is completely fixed in the coming update, and we're trying to make sure we have everything ready before release, as it includes the much better cheat catcher and a fix for the non-latin user names as well. the foundation is considering running some cheat tests  after activation which when foiled, will allow miners and stakers to make something on the cheats that the foundation tests.
Should I update the announcement?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Phantaruk7

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Total coin supply, including locked and unlocked is available in the spreadsheet above. I wouldn't say it is a solution that Ethereum wasn't capable of. They haven't done it yet in production. No one that we know of has, and Ethereum's plans to solve it take a different philosophical approach, which ends up with a more complex implementation plan. Verus has a working, elegant, released solution for solving the POS nothing-at-stake problem, which will activate at block 227520 along with Zcash Sapling support.
Probably the best place now to learn about Verus coin is on the project Medium https://medium.com/veruscoin. @benohanlon wrote a great introduction, including public blockchains as a service (PBaaS) in the Pocket Guide, and @John Westbrook 's articles on the nothing-at-stake solution and Sapling give a great overview of what makes VerusCoin different today.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Only in the Verus enhanced Agama on veruscoin.io right now. it also supports lite mode and other Komodo coins. we have an update in the works right now that should be out tomorrow

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @Phantaruk7 I'm not sure about that. You might check the mining channel. I would expect 24 skylake cores to do better than that. if it's a multicore bottleneck issue, you could try a few instances of 6 cores each or the nheqminer, just to see if that's the issue.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Phantaruk7> Multicore bottleneck means that the Miner cant handle ALL the cores power and the performance goes down?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> it means that there may be a frequently updated shared memory location that requires bus locking and/or spin locks. on few cores, this may be a very small amount of the total overhead, but as the cores increase, it can't scale, and eventually, synchronization consumes a large part of the overhead. in the wallet and nheqminer, i made sure multiple cores would not have this issue. Chris's ccminer beats my loop by interleaving 4 hashes at once, but if there is a multicore bottleneck, that will takeover at some point and nheqminer would win above a certain number of cores. alternately, you can take advatage of the speed in ccminer and divide your cores among multiple instances that don't share the same synchronization objects

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Phantaruk7> Oh i see, is there any tutorial for this nheqminer? @miketout

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> There are releases and some instructions here: https://github.com/VerusCoin/nheqminer/releases
I still think you may do better running multiple instances of ccminer to split up the cores

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Phantaruk7> @miketout  ok if i run multiple instances how much cores do you recommend?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> you can try one instance at 4 or 6 to see what the performance is, and if it scales to the value you're seeing at 24. if not, you can choose 6 instances at 4 cores or the other way around, I would suspect. i would like to know if after running the test of 6 cores, it is much faster per core than at 24.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Phantaruk7> i tried to run the nheqminer benchmark

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Phantaruk7> 445mh/s is this accurate?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that should be accurate and the ccminer when running without core contention should be at least 50% better

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <LocoMB> Morning! Just to be sure, I should ask:
can I keep using Komodo Agama wallet or rather the seed and wifkey for my VERUSCOIN exported with Agama?
the reason why I ask is that Ihave not quite yet understood whether VERUS is a full Komodo clone that will at some point diverge from Komodo or whether it will remain in the same scope of keyspaces... ‚ùî üåê

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <LocoMB> and how does the wallet on VRS website:
Agama-linux-x64-v0.4.0a.tar.gz
relate to Agama 43c?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Hi, and welcome to the community! Here was my answer on Bitcointalk:
You can still use the same seed and WIF key for both wallets and all Komodo family coins. Verus is not really a clone as much as a friendly fork with its own technology and features. At the same time, we intend to remain compatible with Komodo as an ecosystem coin, meaning we intend to remain compatible with formats and share technologies. Sapling keys, for example are not supported yet in Komodo, but when they are, they will be compatible, as we will work with Komodo to integrate compatible changes. We have our own work on Verus Enhanced Agama, and though we expect a lot of our changes to be picked up by Komodo's Agama, they are also making changes, so there is not 100% overlap. We do pick up changes from them and vice versa. We will either converge changes more regularly or rebrand our version of the GUI wallet at some point with attribution. Until then, you should consider them generally compatible with feature differences, and you will need the Verus enhanced wallet to run Verus.

We are working on a Verus Branded, React Native mobile wallet as well, which will also be compatible with the same seeds and WIF keys. Until that is released, we recommend using the Agama or Pungo wallet on mobile.
